Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Understanding the Ecology of School Bullying

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
To date, 49 states have anti-bullying laws and all 50 have policies in place to protect youth from conflict in schools, yet we know little about how these initiatives are locally experienced, what effects they have, and how these effects vary for youth and their families based on social location. Drawing on theoretical tools from cultural sociology, this study seeks to expand empirical understandings of youth conflict by asking what bullying practices and anti-bullying policies accomplish and exploring what meanings they generate. Using an ethnographic approach, this study will look at how youth experience both conflict and bullying response, as well as the varying ways attention to bullying may obscure how young people engage in, and are affected by, inequality within school settings.

Understanding the Ecology of School Bullying is an ethnographic study of the effects of bullying practices and anti-bullying initiatives within a high school community in the Northeast. This project ethnographically approaches bullying as a set of behaviors that emerge from a context-specific set of interdependent relationships among individuals, families, communities, and institutional norms and ideologies. The field site is a rural high school that, like many US schools today, is expressly committed to eradicating bullying among its student body and fostering a positive school climate. Through intensive fieldwork, observations of students' use of social media, and interviews with between 80 and 100 youth, parents, and school officials, this study examines how communities respond to experiences with youth conflict as well as their experiences with anti-bullying initiatives. In addition to offering contributions to sociological scholarship, this study will accessibly speak to a broad social science audience, and help policy makers make better-informed decisions that take into account the multiple effects that anti-bullying initiatives have on school communities and the lives of young people.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study uses an ethnographic approach to explore the effects of anti-bullying policies and youth conflict within a Northeastern high school. While research on bullying has proliferated over the past two decades, there have been few studies that ethnographically explore the micro-processes that influence and shape youth conflict within specific school communities. Today, all 50 states have anti-bullying laws and most US schools have policies in place to protect youth from conflict in schools. However, we know little about how these laws and policies are experienced, what effects they have, and how these effects vary for youth based on social location. This dissertation approaches bullying as an ecology—as a set of behaviors that emerge from a context-specific set of interdependent relationships among individuals, families, communities, and institutional norms and ideologies. The field site is a small-town, rural high school that, like many US schools today, is expressly committed to eradicating bullying among its student body and fostering a positive school climate. Through intensive fieldwork, observations of 75 students’ use of social media, and interviews with 127 youth, teachers and school officials, this study explores how gender, class, race, and sexuality shape this community’s experiences with youth conflict as well as their experiences with anti-bullying initiatives. Analysis reveals that teens’ bullying practices are motivated by the underlying inequalities present within this community. Further, data shows that the anti-bullying policies and initiatives employed unintentionally reinforce existing forms of inequality among teens, and result in further alienation and social isolation for those students who are transgender, low income, and racial and/or sexual minorities.

The intellectual merits of this project are threefold. First, drawing on theoretical tools from cultural sociology, this project expands empirical understandings of youth conflict by asking not what bullying is, but what bullying does. It explores the varying meanings that bullying produces, as well as the varying contextual factors that make bullying a problematic, yet useful resource for youth. Second, bullying is a discourse that is increasingly used to talk about practices that often involve homophobia, racism, classism, and sexism. Examining the local contexts that shape young people’s engagement in these practices, as well as with these concepts, contributes to scholarship on how youth both enforce and resist the reproduction of inequality. Third, this project expands knowledge on bullying by exploring the multiple effects anti-bullying initiatives have on school communities, interrogating not simply how bullying prevention works, but the varying meanings that bullying prevention and response produces. Applying an ethnographic approach to a subject that is widely studied through survey methods has generated a nuanced understanding of the varying ways youth experience both teen conflict and anti-bullying policies and initiatives, as well as the varying ways attention to bullying obscures how young people engage in, and are impacted by, inequality within school settings.

Through extensive ethnographic data collection, this study illuminates the intended and unintended effects of anti-bullying policies and practices on youth, highlighting the reproduction of inequality along multiple axes, and through the interaction of the cultural practices of adults and youth within the school. In addition to offering contributions to sociological scholarship on bullying, education, youth, and culture, the findings of this research have significant educational policy implications. Policy is best shaped by research from a variety of methodologies, informed by both quantitative and qualitative research. To date, anti-bullying policies and initiatives are largely informed by survey data that often cannot speak to the micro-social processes and intersecting roles that bullying practices and responses play in educational settings. The findings of this dissertation offer innovative qualitative insights to this topic, indicating that anti-bullying policies and initiatives are not effective in isolation. They need to take place in tandem with a variety of educational programming and practices that comprehensively address race, class, gender, sexuality, healthy relationships, and social justice. Policy makers will benefit from knowledge about teens’ lived experiences that illustrate the multiple impacts of policies that routinely govern young lives. This study is designed to accessibly speak to a broad social science audience, to help educators develop better strategies for dealing with bullying that integrally address the underlying inequalities that so frequently motivate teens’ conflicts, and to help policy makers make better-informed decisions that take into account the multiple effects that anti-bullying policies have on school communities and the lives of young people.
